docs.lead_paragraph: During the eight years he held the post of United States Surgeon General, Dr. C. Everett Koop became one of the country's most authoritative and recognizable public figures on the subject of health. But more than a decade after leaving office, Dr. Koop, now 82, is facing criticism, from medical ethicists, including two representatives of the American Medical Association, consumer advocates and others.

headline.main: E-MEDICINE -- A special report.; Hailed as a Surgeon General, Koop Is Faulted on Web Ethics

docs.abstract: Dr C Everett Koop, esteemed former surgeon general, is facing criticism from American Medical Association and medical ethicists that his hugely popular health data Web site, DrKoop.com, often blurs line between objective information and its advertising or promotional content and that his ties to business have not been properly disclosed; site only recently posted notice that company and Koop are entitled to commission on products and services sold because of site; Koop gave up those commissions Aug 27; photos (M)
docs.snippet: During the eight years he held the post of United States Surgeon General, Dr. C. Everett Koop became one of the country's most authoritative and recognizable public figures on the subject of health.    But more than a decade after leaving office, Dr....

docs.lead_paragraph: Along the wooded glacial ridges of central New York, water burbles from the earth in countless torrents and trickles. It tumbles north to the Mohawk River, or south to the Susquehanna or the Delaware. The impression these forest fountains made on English settlers lingers in place names like Richfield Springs, Springfield and, most famously, Sharon Springs, where Russian immigrants repair in summer to the same bathhouses used by New York City's potentates a century ago. Somehow, Cherry Valley, 12 miles northeast of Cooperstown, missed out, and was named instead for the black cherry trees that grew wild in the hollows.

headline.main: A Spring's Prospects Have a Town Smiling; In Cherry Valley, a Water Source Has a Story, and Perhaps a Future

docs.abstract: Cherry Vally, NY, residents want to resurrect spring whose water, local lore has it, lifts one's spirits; spring contains lithium, element that is standard treatment for manic-depressive illness; spring fell into disuse about 20 years ago, victim of neglect and modern plumbing; photo (M)
